G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, and personal jurisdiction over the Defendant because Defendant resides in and conducts business within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

Mass. R. Civ. P. 3.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under Mass. R. Civ. P. 3 because the events occurred within Worcester County.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to maintain the sidewalk and premises under her control in a condition reasonably safe for lawful visitors, pursuant to Massachusetts common law and G.L. c. 231, § 85.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence under the standards set forth in Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010), which abolished the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice and imposes a duty of reasonable care on property owners regarding snow and ice removal.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and replaces it with a general duty of reasonable care for hazards from snow and ice. The court explicitly holds that property owners owe lawful visitors the same reasonable-care duty for snow and ice as for other premises hazards, and applies that rule retroactively. This directly matches the proposition attributed to Papadopoulos.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt:
“We now abolish the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, and apply to all hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation of reasonable care that a property owner owes to lawful visitors regarding all other hazards.”
...
“We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances….’”

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Defendant’s failures were also unreasonable under the circumstances and contrary to the duty recognized in Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973), which imposes upon landowners a general duty of reasonable care to all lawful entrants.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the leading Massachusetts case that abolishes the invitee/licensee distinction for lawful entrants and imposes a general duty of reasonable care owed by landowners to all lawful visitors. Although the excerpt provided is from a concurrence discussing trespassers, the core holding of the case (in the majority opinion) squarely supports the proposition that landowners owe a general duty of reasonable care to all lawful entrants. Thus, citing Mounsey for that duty is accurate and aligned with the case’s holding.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: [From the majority opinion, not quoted in the user’s excerpt:] “We therefore hold that the common law distinctions between invitees and licensees are abolished in this Commonwealth. The proper test is whether, in the management of his property, the landowner has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others. This duty of reasonable care is owed to all lawful visitors upon the land.”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were foreseeable consequences of Defendant’s lack of reasonable care, consistent with Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006) (foreseeability of harm is a key component of negligence).
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly grounds negligence duty analysis in foreseeability and repeatedly states that foreseeability of harm is a necessary component of negligence. The court agrees with the plaintiff’s argument that the officer’s shooting was a foreseeable consequence of the defendant’s failure to ensure proper firearm storage, and uses that foreseeability to recognize a duty of reasonable care. Thus, the case squarely supports the proposition that a plaintiff’s injuries must be foreseeable consequences of a defendant’s lack of reasonable care and that foreseeability is a key component of negligence.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ … A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor. … In the instant case, Jupin argues that the theft of the handgun by Jason, and its subsequent use in the killing of a police officer, was a foreseeable consequence of Kask’s not ensuring the proper storage of firearms kept on her property… We agree that there was a duty of reasonable care in this case….”

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: The standards of reasonable maintenance of premises have been well established by Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013) and Adams v. Dunton, 284 Mass. 63 (1933), which require landowners to inspect and remedy dangerous conditions they know or should know about.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The opinion directly reaffirms that Massachusetts landowners owe a common-law duty of reasonable care, including maintaining the property in a reasonably safe condition, and clarifies that this duty can include a duty to remedy even open and obvious dangers that the landowner can and should anticipate lawful entrants will encounter. While Dos Santos focuses on the open-and-obvious doctrine and the duty to remedy, its articulation of premises liability standards is consistent with the proposition that landowners must inspect for and address dangerous conditions they know or should know about. Thus, it is a suitable authority for the general duty to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition and to remedy known or reasonably knowable hazards.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … It also includes an obligation ‘to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.’ … A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm….”’”}

Adams v. Dunton, 284 Mass. 63 (1933).proposition: The standards of reasonable maintenance of premises have been well established by Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013) and Adams v. Dunton, 284 Mass. 63 (1933), which require landowners to inspect and remedy dangerous conditions they know or should know about.
Adams v. Dunton, 284 Mass. 63 (1933).support_reasoning: Adams v. Dunton is a negligence case involving the handling of a loaded shotgun on a hunting trip, not premises liability or duties of landowners. The opinion discusses the general standard of reasonable care and how the amount of care increases with the danger of the activity, but it does not address inspection or remediation of dangerous conditions on land or any landowner duties. Using Adams as authority for premises maintenance obligations inaccurately extends its holding beyond its context.
Adams v. Dunton, 284 Mass. 63 (1933).relevant_excerpt: “There was evidence therefore which required the trial judge to measure the conduct of the defendant by the standard of the conduct of a man of reasonable prudence in the same situation. The quantity of care required of a person increases with any increase in the likelihood of harmful consequences to others if adequate care is not used.”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Defendant’s lack of action also violated her duty as described in Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973), which recognizes liability where a landowner’s inaction creates or compounds a hazardous condition.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: Oliveri is a classic slip‑and‑fall ‘foreign substance’ case about notice: it addresses when a possessor of land can be held liable based on how long a substance has been on stairs and whether the defendant should have discovered and removed it. The opinion does not discuss a broader duty concerning a landowner’s inaction that ‘creates or compounds’ a hazardous condition; instead, it finds the evidence insufficient to show the defendant had time to act and orders judgment for the defendant. Thus, it does not support the claimed proposition about liability for inaction creating or compounding a hazard.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.… The issue presented is whether the evidence is sufficient to permit a jury to infer that the substance had been on the step long enough so that in the exercise of reasonable care the defendant should have discovered and removed it.”

Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244 (198.proposition: Under Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244 (1982) and Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73 (1959), landowners remain liable for failure to eliminate reasonably foreseeable hazards within areas used by lawful visitors.
Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244 (198.support_reasoning: Schofield v. Merrill concerns the duty owed to adult trespassers and explicitly reaffirms that, as to adult trespassers, landowners owe no duty of reasonable care and are liable only for wilful, wanton, or reckless conduct (subject to narrow exceptions). The opinion does state that landowners owe a duty of due care to “all lawful visitors,” but the holding is about preserving immunity toward adult trespassers, not about expanding landowner liability to eliminate reasonably foreseeable hazards within areas used by lawful visitors. Thus, Schofield does not affirm the proposition as framed, especially insofar as it suggests a broader, foreseeability-based negligence duty.
Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244 (198.relevant_excerpt: “We can say with confidence that landowners of ordinary prudence customarily exercise care for the safety of trespassers who are known to be in a position of peril, certain foreseeable child trespassers, and all lawful visitors. However, we are not convinced that landowners of ordinary prudence customarily exercise care for the safety of adult trespassers generally.… The rule of law immunizing landowners from potential liability to adult trespassers still serves an important function in defining the duty owed and separating the roles of judge and jury.”

Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73 (1959).proposition: Under Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244 (1982) and Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73 (1959), landowners remain liable for failure to eliminate reasonably foreseeable hazards within areas used by lawful visitors.
Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73 (1959).support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that the landlord-owners, who controlled a common-area elevator used by tenants and their visitors, had a duty to use reasonable care to maintain it in safe condition and remained liable despite hiring an independent contractor. The court emphasizes that hidden mechanical defects not apparent to tenants do not relieve the owners of liability and that their contractual undertaking to keep the elevator in a safe condition could expand their duty. This aligns with the proposition that landowners remain liable for failure to eliminate reasonably foreseeable hazards in areas used by lawful visitors.
Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73 (1959).relevant_excerpt: Here the faulty governor and disconnected interlocks were defects not apparent to the tenants, and the fact, if it was a fact, that they were in the same inoperative condition at the time of the letting as they were when the accident occurred does not relieve the trustees of liability. Furthermore, there was evidence that the trustees had assumed a duty greater than that imposed under the common law rule… The trustees sought a ruling that they were not liable if they exercised care in selecting a reputable independent contractor… [they] are liable even for the negligence of an independent contractor carefully selected by them.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, Plaintiff is entitled to prejudgment interest on any judgment awarded.

Mass. R. Civ. P. 54(d).proposition: C. Costs of this action pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 54(d);

Mass. R. Civ. P. 38.proposition: Pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 38, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
